title: Aesthetic and Literary Terminology
description: Specialized vocabulary for literary criticism and aesthetic theory

items.definition: A manuscript written over earlier writing; something bearing visible traces of its history
items.example: The city is a palimpsest of architectural styles from different eras.

items.definition: Of such excellence or grandeur as to inspire awe; in aesthetics, that which exceeds comprehension
items.example: Burke distinguished between the beautiful and the sublime, associating the latter with terror.

items.definition: A vivid literary description of a work of visual art
items.example: Keats's 'Ode on a Grecian Urn' is a celebrated example of ekphrasis.

items.definition: Relating to a transitional or threshold stage; between states
items.example: Adolescence occupies a liminal space between childhood and adulthood.

items.definition: The appearance of being true or real; believability in fiction
items.example: The novel's verisimilitude depends on its attention to period detail.

items.definition: The artistic technique of presenting common things in unfamiliar ways to enhance perception
items.example: Shklovsky argued that defamiliarization is the essence of art.

items.definition: The coexistence of multiple varieties of speech or points of view within a text
items.example: Bakhtin celebrated the novel's capacity for heteroglossia.

items.definition: Relating to knowledge of God or ultimate reality obtained by negation; describing what something is not
items.example: The apophatic tradition in mysticism approaches the divine through negation.
